subsection.title: Describing lines and planes parametrically
subsection.p: First we will work out some of the activities from that involve describing lines and planes parametrically.

warning.p:
In the previous example, we determined the value of the parameter t that corresponds to the point (4,1/2) on the line by solving vector equation . When you are solving vector equations for parameters like this, make sure you check that your solution works in every coordinate! For example, in
we see that t=1/2 immediately from comparing the second coordinate on left and right. But it is important to check that this parameter value also works in the first coordinate (which it does).

example.title: Parametrically describing the intersection of two planes in \R^3

statement.p:
In , we considered a system consisting of two equations in three variables,
\left\{\begin{array}{rcrcrcr} 2x \amp - \amp y \amp + \amp z \amp = \amp 3\text{,} \\ x \amp + \amp 3y \amp - \amp 2z \amp = \amp -1\text{.} \end{array}\right.
Geometrically, each of the equations represents a plane in space, and solutions to the system represent points that are in common to both planes ( points in the intersection of the two planes). From the coefficients of the equations we may take \uvec{n}_1 = (2,-1,1) and \uvec{n}_2 = (1,3,-2) as normal vectors for the two planes, respectively. Since these normal vectors are not parallel, neither are the planes, and so they must intersect. Algebraically, this means that the coefficient parts of the two equations are not multiples of each other, so when we row reduce we will find two leading ones, representing the two independent equations with which we started. And so we will only require one parameter to express the general solution, which will then take the form of a line. The free variable in this system is z, so setting z to parameter t and solving we get
\uvec{x} = \begin{bmatrix}x \\[0.5ex] y \\[0.5ex] z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{8}{7}-\frac{t}{7} \\[6pt] -\frac{5}{7} + \frac{5t}{7} \\[0.5ex] t \end{bmatrix} = \left[\begin{array}{r} \frac{8}{7} \\[0.5ex] -\frac{5}{7} \\[0.5ex] 0 \end{array}\right] + t\left[\begin{array}{r} -\frac{1}{7} \\[0.5ex] \frac{5}{7} \\[0.5ex] 1 \end{array}\right].
Here, the initial point corresponding to t=0 is \uvec{x}_0 = (8/7,-5/7,0), and the vector \uvec{p} = (-1/7,5/7,1) is parallel to the line.

subsection.title: Determining points of intersection
subsection.p: When lines and/or planes are described using algebraic equations, determining points of intersection only requires solving the linear systems that those equations form together. Here we will demonstrate determining points of intersection when some or all of the lines and/or planes involved are described parametrically by working out some of the activities from .

example.title: Intersection of a parametrically-described line and an algebraically-described plane in \R^3

statement.p:
In , we have a line described by a vector equation and a plane described algebraically, and would like to determine their point of intersection (if there is one). Any such point of intersection must be on the line, and so its coordinates can be described in terms of the parameter t:
\uvec{x} = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 0 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix} + t \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] = \begin{bmatrix} 2-t \\ t \\ 3+t \end{bmatrix}.
If this point is also on the plane, its coordinates must satisfy the equation for the plane:
2x+y-3z \amp= 7 \\ 2(2-t) + t - 3(3+t) \amp= 7 \\ -5 - 4t \amp= 7 \\ t \amp= -3.
Substituting this parameter value in our expression for \uvec{x} gives us the point of intersection: \left[\begin{array}{r} 5 \\ -3 \\ 0 \end{array}\right].

aside.title: Check your understanding
aside.p: What if the line and plane had been parallel with no point of intersection? What would have happened when we tried to solve for t? Or, what if the line and plane had been parallel, but with the line lying inside the plane? How would this have become evident from the algebra of attempting to solve for t?
